content.raw: Based on [other PRs](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-cmake/pull-requests/24/add-findogrecmake/activity#comment-52732024) I think the print-outs can be removed
content.html: Based on other PRs I think the print-outs can be removed

content.raw:
The print-outs can be useful when performing a manual search like this (i.e. not using `ign_pkg_check_modules` or `find_package`) because the automatic search functions will print out status updates on the search progress, whereas these manual search functions (`find_path` and `find_library`) will not.

However, we should definitely wrap these messages in `if(NOT YAML_FIND_QUIETLY)` so that callers have the option to suppress these printouts.
content.html:
The print-outs can be useful when performing a manual search like this (i.e. not using ign_pkg_check_modules or find_package) because the automatic search functions will print out status updates on the search progress, whereas these manual search functions (find_path and find_library) will not.

However, we should definitely wrap these messages in if(NOT YAML_FIND_QUIETLY) so that callers have the option to suppress these printouts.

content.raw: Since we don't generally expect the config-file to be available (apparently it's only available if the user installed from the source code using cmake), I would suggest that we throw away `yaml_quiet_arg` and always pass in `QUIET` here. CMake emits a rather aggressive warning when a config-file is missing, and I don't want to alarm our users.
content.html: Since we don't generally expect the config-file to be available (apparently it's only available if the user installed from the source code using cmake), I would suggest that we throw away yaml_quiet_arg and always pass in QUIET here. CMake emits a rather aggressive warning when a config-file is missing, and I don't want to alarm our users.

content.raw:
This line seems strange to me. This would imply that the `pkg-config` module name is `yaml-0.1`. In other words, it will look for a `yaml-0.1.pc` file in a `pkgconfig/` directory. This also disagrees with line 33.

In general, the arguments provided to `ign_pkg_check_modules(~)` should perfectly match any arguments that would be given to `ign_pkg_config_entry(~)` and vice-versa.
content.html:
This line seems strange to me. This would imply that the pkg-config module name is yaml-0.1. In other words, it will look for a yaml-0.1.pc file in a pkgconfig/ directory. This also disagrees with line 33.

In general, the arguments provided to ign_pkg_check_modules(~) should perfectly match any arguments that would be given to ign_pkg_config_entry(~) and vice-versa.

content.raw:
After installing `libyaml-dev`, I've come to the realization that `yaml-0.1.pc` **is** actually the name of their pkg-config file (I feel like including the minor version in the module name is a bit extreme, but I can't really criticize since we include the major version in ours).

So really, it's line 33 that should be changed. I guess I would also recommend removing the ` = ${YAML_VERSION}` from line 33 since the module name itself will apparently contain both the major and minor version information.
content.html:
After installing libyaml-dev, I've come to the realization that yaml-0.1.pc is actually the name of their pkg-config file (I feel like including the minor version in the module name is a bit extreme, but I can't really criticize since we include the major version in ours).

So really, it's line 33 that should be changed. I guess I would also recommend removing the = ${YAML_VERSION} from line 33 since the module name itself will apparently contain both the major and minor version information.

content.raw:
The main thing I don't like about this is it makes it difficult/dangerous for anyone to request a specific version of `libyaml` from the find-module.

My first instinct would be to say that we should use a variable here, so we'd have `ign_pkg_check_modules(YAML yaml-${YAML_VERSION})`, but then if `ign_find_package(YAML ...)` is called without specifying a version, then we'd be telling `pkg-config` to look for a file named `yaml-.pc` which is obviously wrong. I see two options for making this find-module robust:

1. We could check `if(${YAML_VERSION} VERSION_EQUAL "0.1")` and emit a configuration error when that check fails. This would prevent us from misconfiguring our `pkg-config` file, but it would require us to change the find-module in order to fix it.

2. We could set a default `set(ign_yaml_version 0.1)` and then check `if(YAML_VERSION)`, and then set `ign_yaml_version` based on `YAML_VERSION` if something has been specified. The danger there is the user needs to know that they have to provide a `<version>` that matches an existing `yaml-<version>.pc`.
content.html:
The main thing I don't like about this is it makes it difficult/dangerous for anyone to request a specific version of libyaml from the find-module.

My first instinct would be to say that we should use a variable here, so we'd have ign_pkg_check_modules(YAML yaml-${YAML_VERSION}), but then if ign_find_package(YAML ...) is called without specifying a version, then we'd be telling pkg-config to look for a file named yaml-.pc which is obviously wrong. I see two options for making this find-module robust:

  1. We could check if(${YAML_VERSION} VERSION_EQUAL "0.1") and emit a configuration error when that check fails. This would prevent us from misconfiguring our pkg-config file, but it would require us to change the find-module in order to fix it.

  2. We could set a default set(ign_yaml_version 0.1) and then check if(YAML_VERSION), and then set ign_yaml_version based on YAML_VERSION if something has been specified. The danger there is the user needs to know that they have to provide a <version> that matches an existing yaml-<version>.pc.

content.raw:
I need to apologize, because I've accidentally been giving out incorrect information.

We don't want to use `<package>_VERSION`, we want to use `<package>_FIND_VERSION`. The variable `<package>_VERSION` is produced when `find_package(~)` uses config-mode, but if we're in this find-module, then that means `find_package(~)` is using module-mode. In module-mode, it sets the variable `<package>_FIND_VERSION`, similar to `<package>_FIND_QUIETLY`.
content.html:
I need to apologize, because I've accidentally been giving out incorrect information.

We don't want to use <package>_VERSION, we want to use <package>_FIND_VERSION. The variable <package>_VERSION is produced when find_package(~) uses config-mode, but if we're in this find-module, then that means find_package(~) is using module-mode. In module-mode, it sets the variable <package>_FIND_VERSION, similar to <package>_FIND_QUIETLY.

content.raw: Actually, it seems that `libyaml` does not provide a config-file, neither in their [debian package](https://packages.ubuntu.com/xenial/amd64/libyaml-dev/filelist) nor in their [source code](https://bitbucket.org/xi/libyaml/src/6d5f97d23301?at=default) (assuming that's the correct repo), so we should just remove this line until such a time that they do provide one.
content.html: Actually, it seems that libyaml does not provide a config-file, neither in their debian package nor in their source code (assuming that's the correct repo), so we should just remove this line until such a time that they do provide one.

content.raw: CMake provides a [VERSION_EQUAL](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.5/command/if.html) which I think we should prefer over `STREQUAL`. Using `VERSION_EQUAL` should allow this test to pass if they specify `0` or `0.1.#`, which I think should be desirable.
content.html: CMake provides a VERSION_EQUAL which I think we should prefer over STREQUAL. Using VERSION_EQUAL should allow this test to pass if they specify 0 or 0.1.#, which I think should be desirable.

content.raw:
This is super nitpicky, but I like to align the split quotes with the string that they split off from. E.g.

```
message(WARNING "Here is the first line of a message "
                "and here is some more of the message")
```

Also, there's a space at the end of the first split and the beginning of the second split, so we may want to remove one of those.

These would be completely superficial changes, though, so I approve of this PR whether or not these suggestions are taken.
content.html:
